thread.title: Standard Chartered, oil firms push FTSE 100 higher
thread.title_full: Standard Chartered, oil firms push FTSE 100 higher - MarketWatch

author: By     Sara Sjolin
title: Standard Chartered, oil firms push FTSE 100 higher
text:
U.K. stocks kicked off the week in upbeat fashion on Monday, with Standard Chartered PLC and Royal Dutch Shell PLC helping to push the main benchmark higher after company-specific news.
The FTSE 100 index UKX, +0.20% climbed 0.2% to close at 6,788.69, building on a 1.5% gain from last week.
Including Monday’s advance, the London benchmark has now moved higher eight out of the past nine sessions on optimism that Greece’s debt crisis is abating. The country’s banks opened on Monday after being shut for three weeks.
In London, banks were in the spotlight, with Standard Chartered STAN, +0.93% climbing 0.9%. The gain came as the bank’s new, American-born chief executive Bill Winters announced a reorganization of the company , which is expected to cut costs and boost efficiency.
Among other banks on the rise, HSBC Holdings PLC HSBA, +1.12% HSBC, +0.93% 0005, +0.71% gained 1.1%.
Barclays PLC BARC, +0.27% BCS, -0.17% moved 0.3% higher after media reports that the lender plans to slash more than 30,000 of its staff within two years.
Shares of Royal Dutch Shell RDSB, +0.46% RDS.B, -0.47% picked up 0.5% after the Financial Times reported that the oil giant expects cost savings from the planned BG PLC BG., +0.98% takeover to be much greater than previously disclosed and exceed billions of dollars.
BG Group shares added 1%.
Meanwhile, shares of gold miners declined as the price of the metal slumped. Randgold Resources Ltd. RRS, -4.67% GOLD, -4.33% fell 4.7%, while Fresnillo PLC FRES, -4.41% lost 4.4%.
Outside the main index in London, shares of Aveva Group PLC AVV, +27.31% soared 27% after Schneider Electric SE SU, +0.55% said it plans to take a controlling stake in the U.K.-based engineering software provider.
